block.p: IN the late 90's, residents of one block of West 118th Street in Harlem set out to renew their houses and their community in what was known as the Carmel Hill Project, and Bill Foley recorded their progress in photographs.

Mr. Foley won a Pulitzer Prize for photography in 1983 for recording the aftermath of a massacre in a Palestinian refugee camp. His Carmel Hill pictures some 60 black and white images that depict the area and its inhabitants before and after restoration -- will be on display at the Museum of the City of New York. The image at left, taken in 1998, is of children returning home from school in the neighborhood.

IN the late 90's, residents of one block of West 118th Street in Harlem set out to renew their houses and their community in what was known as the Carmel Hill Project, and Bill Foley recorded their progress in photographs.

Mr. Foley won a Pulitzer Prize for photography in 1983 for recording the aftermath of a massacre in a Palestinian refugee camp. His Carmel Hill pictures some 60 black and white images that depict the area and its inhabitants before and after restoration -- will be on display at the Museum of the City of New York. The image at left, taken in 1998, is of children returning home from school in the neighborhood.
The project, covering the block between Lenox and Fifth Avenues, was sponsored in part by the Children's Aid Society with the support of William J. Ruane, a Wall Street fund manager.
A five-minute video clip produced by NBC News that focuses on Mr. Ruane and Mr. Foley will be shown as part of the exhibition.

''Renewing a Block and the Spirit of Its People: Photographs of Carmel Hill, Harlem, by Bill Foley'' opens Saturday, through Nov. 12; Museum of the City of New York; Wednesday through Saturday 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., Tuesday 10 a.m. to 2 p.m., registered groups only Sunday noon to 5 p.m.; 1220 Fifth Avenue, at 103rd Street; suggested donation: $7; students, children and people over 65, $4; families, $12; (212) 534-1672.
